Award.AwardTitle: CSMP Scholarship Program at Central Connecticut State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Central Connecticut State University (CCSU) program is attracting and retaining academically talented and under-represented students from low-income and disadvantaged families to achieve degrees in Computer Science, Mathematics and Physics (CSMP) by offering them financial support, academic support, and enrichment opportunities. The program is targeting prospective students recruited through public schools, two-year colleges and community organizations, as well as promising students enrolled in CSMP and related programs at CCSU. Scholars are being assigned faculty mentors and are receiving a wide range of support in academic and career planning, mentoring, counseling, and internships. CSMP fields are providing research-rich learning environments that offer students the opportunity to participate in a variety of ongoing research projects with an emphasis on interdisciplinary work. Student cohorts are creating a supportive environment for scholars ensuring their academic success, retention and timely graduation. An established, well-functioning student support infrastructure coupled with faculty and staff experienced in mentoring under-represented students is helping minorities, female, and first-generation students achieve their education goals. This is leading to a strong and diverse workforce for CSMP. Student research and publication experiences are building a graduate pipeline of under-represented students into the academy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics (CSMP) scholarship program at Central Connecticut State University (CCSU) was created to improve the chances for academic success for underrepresented but academically talented students in these three academic disciplines. From 2011 through 2016, our program supported thirty-seven undergraduate students at CCSU. Twenty-eight of these students (76%) reported being accepted into graduate programs at various universities. 

We actively solicited applications and advertised the scholarship program among area high schools and community colleges. 

Intellectual merits of the program included providing ample opportunities for student community building. An important feature utilized in our program was a combination of activities that strengthen the student cohort along with a personalized approach to mentoring students by faculty. We organized and supported a wide range of seminars, lectures, and social events offered to all members of the scholarship program, as well as to the entire campus community. These activities helped create a stronger sense of a closely-knit community of our students coming from three CSMP disciplines.

The program provided a range of broader impacts to the society. Organizing and disseminating the information about the events described above helped strengthen a consistent stream of information about what is going on in CSMP academic departments, our academic programs, what current research topics we are investigating, what topics are currently of interest to our students, etc. This information was disseminated to the broader campus community and beyond building the general awareness about computer science, mathematics, and physics among people who may not be generally inclined to seek this type of information. We believe, building this type of awareness among the general population is very important in order to help highlight the role that science plays in our everyday lives.
